{"nickname": "Apollo","gender": "male"}: ä¼ è¾“æ•°æ®

è¯·æ±‚æ–¹æ³•

status code

In HTTP, you send a numeric status code of 3 digits as part of the response.
These status codes have a name associated to recognize them, but the important part is the number.

In short:
100 - 199 are for â€œInformationâ€. You rarely use them directly. Responses with these status codes cannot have a body.
200 - 299 are for â€œSuccessfulâ€ responses. These are the ones you would use the most.
200 is the default status code, which means everything was â€œOKâ€.
Another example would be 201, â€œCreatedâ€. It is commonly used after creating a new record in the database.
A special case is 204, â€œNo Contentâ€. This response is used when there is no content to return to the client, and so the response must not have a body.
300 - 399 are for â€œRedirectionâ€. Responses with these status codes may or may not have a body, except for 304, â€œNot Modifiedâ€, which must not have one.
400 - 499 are for â€œClient errorâ€ responses. These are the second type you would probably use the most.
An example is 404, for a â€œNot Foundâ€ response.
For generic errors from the client, you can just use 400.
500 - 599 are for server errors. You almost never use them directly. When something goes wrong at some part in your application code, or server, it will automatically return one of these status codes.

Request Body

A request body is data sent by the client to your API. A response body is the data your API sends to the client.

Your API almost always has to send a response body. But clients donâ€™t necessarily need to send request bodies all the time, sometimes they only request a path, maybe with some query parameters, but donâ€™t send a body.
